THE NATURE CONSERVANCY WILL BE AWARDED $3,267,129 FOR THE DESIGN, PERMITTING, AND IMPLEMENTATION OF EIGHT PROJECTS WITHIN THE FLOODPLAIN OF THE LOWER ROANOKE RIVER, COLLECTIVELY COMPRISING 1,130 ACRES OF FLOODPLAIN HABITAT AND MORE THAN 5 MILES OF RECONNECTED RIVER. THE EFFORT WILL REPLACE SIX UNDERSIZED CULVERTS WITH BRIDGES AND REMOVE TWO EARTHEN BARRIERS. REMOVAL OF THESE BARRIERS COMPLEMENTS NOAA'S EFFORTS WITH UPSTREAM PROJECTS TO REHYDRATE THE FLOODPLAIN. RESTORATION WILL GREATLY BENEFIT BLUEBACK HERRING AND OTHER ALOSINES DIRECTLY AND ATLANTIC STURGEON INDIRECTLY. THE PROJECTS WILL ALSO PROVIDE CLIMATE AND ECOLOGICAL RESILIENCE BY REDUCING FLOODING AND IMPROVING WATER QUALITY IN THE WATERSHED. THE PROJECTS WILL OCCUR WITHIN ECONOMICALLY DISADVANTAGED, RURAL AREAS.

THE ATLANTIC SALMON FEDERATION WILL BE AWARDED $7,554,797 TO ADDRESS FISH PASSAGE BARRIERS IN THE PENOBSCOT RIVER WATERSHED, PARTICULARLY THE PISCATAQUIS BASIN, TO SUPPORT AND IMPROVE THE LARGEST ATLANTIC SALMON RUN IN THE UNITED STATES. REMOVING TWO DAMS AND INSTALLING FISH LADDERS AT TWO OTHERS WILL OPEN SITES THAT ARE CURRENTLY COMPLETE BARRIERS TO FISH PASSAGE. THE PROJECTS ARE IDENTIFIED IN, OR CONSISTENT WITH, THE ATLANTIC SALMON RECOVERY PLAN AND THE ATLANTIC SALMON SPECIES IN THE SPOTLIGHT 5-YEAR ACTION PLAN. REMOVAL OF THE GUILFORD DAM WILL RECONNECT MORE THAN 9,700 SUITABLE HABITAT UNITS TOWARDS THE DELISTING CRITERIA OF 30,000 UNITS FOR THE PENOBSCOT BASIN SALMON HABITAT RECOVERY UNIT. THE PROJECT WILL ALSO SUPPORT THE TOWN OF DOVER-FOXCROFT IN CONDUCTING A FEASIBILITY STUDY TO EXAMINE OPTIONS TO PROVIDE FISH PASSAGE AT MOOSEHEAD DAM.

FUNDING WAS APPROVED IN 2022 THROUGH THE COASTAL WETLANDS PLANNING, PROTECTION, AND RESTORATION ACT (CWPPRA) PROGRAM FOR CONSTRUCTION OF THE BRETON LANDBRIDGE MARSH CREATION (WEST) RIVER AUX CHENES TO GRAND LAKE (BS-0038) PROJECT. THIS PROJECT WILL RESTORE 423 ACRES OF MARSH IN PLAQUEMINES PARISH, LOUISIANA, TO THE SOUTHEAST OF DELACROIX AND ADD TO EXISTING PROJECTS UNDER CONSTRUCTION TO REBUILD SIGNIFICANT MARSH FEATURES PROMOTING RESILIENCY. LOUISIANA COASTAL PROTECTION AND RESTORATION AUTHORITY, THE LOCAL COST SHARE PARTNER, IS THE LEAD IN DESIGN AND CONSTRUCTION FOR THIS PROJECT WITH NOAA'S ACTIVE ENGAGEMENT. COASTAL WETLANDS ARE LOUISIANA'S FIRST LINE OF DEFENSE DURING HURRICANES AND STORMS, PROTECTING COMMUNITIES AND INFRASTRUCTURE FROM THE DAMAGING EFFECTS OF WIND, WAVES, AND FLOODING. THEY ALSO PROVIDE HABITAT FOR FISH AND SHELLFISH, WHICH SUPPORT A STATEWIDE SEAFOOD INDUSTRY VALUED AT NEARLY $1 BILLION PER YEAR. HOWEVER, THE LOUISIANA COASTLINE HAS DETERIORATED CONSIDERABLY OV

MT ADAMS INSTITUTE WILL BE AWARDED UP TO $814,857 OVER 3 YEARS TO TO RECRUIT, HIRE AND PLACE VETERANS INTERESTED IN NATURAL RESOURCES WITHIN NOAA AND PARTNER AGENCY AND NON-PROFIT OFFICES IN THE PACIFIC REGION, INCLUDING OREGON, CALIFORNIA, WASHINGTON AND ALASKA.  VETERANS WILL RECEIVE TRAINING IN A SERIES OF SKILLS RELATED TO SALMON AND STEELHEAD MONITORING AND RESTORATION.  AFTER PLACEMENT WITH PARTNERS OR NOAA OFFICES, VETERANS WILL ASSIST WITH SALMON AND STEELHEAD POPULATION AND HABITAT MONITORING, PLANNING COMMUNITY DRIVEN RESTORATION PROJECTS AND HELPING TO RESTORE FISHERIES HABITAT.  ONCE 10 MONTHS OF SERVICE IS COMPLETED, VETS WILL BE AWARDED WITH A CERTIFICATE OF COMPLETION OF THE VETSWORK PROGRAM.  THE WORK WILL CONTRIBUTE TO RECOVERY AND SUSTAINABILITY OF SALMON AND STEELHEAD POPULATIONS AND IMPROVE VETERANS CONNECTIONS TO HABITATS THAT SUPPORT NOAA TRUST RESOURCES. THIS WORK IS BEING FUNDED BY THE HABITAT CONSERVATION PROGRAM OFFICE

THE VIRGINIA MARINE RESOURCES COMMISSION WILL WORK WITH NOAA TO CONSTRUCT UP TO 60 ACRES OF SUB-TIDAL OYSTER REEF IN MOBJACK BAY, VIRGINIA, AND TO SITE AND CONSTRUCT A SHORELINE RESILIENCY OYSTER REEF DEMONSTRATION PROJECT OR PROJECTS ON STATE-OWNED OR PUBLIC ACCESS AUTHORITY-OWNED LANDS IN MOBJACK BAY. BOTH THE SUBTIDAL AND SHORELINE WORK WILL TAKE PLACE WITHIN THE NEW NOAA MIDDLE PENINSULA HABITAT FOCUS AREA. THE SUB-TIDAL OYSTER REEF WILL BE CONSTRUCTED PRIMARILY OF CRUSHED STONE AS SUBSTRATE FOR THE REEFS. THE SHORELINE PROJECT IS EXPECTED TO BE CONSTRUCTED USING CONCRETE OYSTER STRUCTURES (I.E. REEF BALL OR REEF CASTLES) OR SIMILAR MATERIALS. REEF CONSTRUCTION WILL TAKE PLACE IN THE SPRING-SUMMER-FALL OF 2023, 2024, 2025, AND 2026. EFFECTS WILL BE INCREASED OYSTER DENSITIES ON THE TARGET SITES, WHICH ARE ANTICIPATED TO BE SELF-SUSTAINING, AND INCREASED ECOSYSTEM SERVICES INCLUDING WATER FILTRATION, POTENTIAL WAVE ATTENUATION AND REDUCED SHORELINE EROSION AT THE SHORELINE PROJECT S

THE MARYLAND DEPARTMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES WILL WORK WITH NOAA, THE OYSTER RECOVERY PARTNERSHIP AND THE UNIVERSITY OF MARYLAND CENTER FOR ENVIRONMENTAL SCIENCE HORN POINT OYSTER HATCHERY TO PLACE HATCHERY-PRODUCED SPAT-ON-SHELL ON UP TO 100 ACRES OF OYSTER REEFS IN FOUR TARGETED TRIBUTARIES (LITTLE CHOPTANK, TRED AVON, ST. MARY'S, AND MANOKIN) IN THE MARYLAND WATERS OF THE CHESAPEAKE BAY. SPAT-ON-SHELL WILL BE PRODUCED BY THE UNIVERSITY OF MARYLAND'S HORN POINT HATCHERY. SEEDING WORK IS PLANNED FOR SPRING-SUMMER-FALL OF 2023, 2024, 2025 AND 2026. EFFECTS WILL BE INCREASED OYSTER DENSITIES ON THE TARGET SITES, WHICH ARE ANTICIPATED TO BE SELF-SUSTAINING, AND INCREASED ECOSYSTEM SERVICES INCLUDING WATER FILTRATION, FISH HABITAT FOR FEDERALLY MANAGED FISH SPECIES, AND INCREASED FISH AND OYSTER SPAWNING CAPACITY.

THE NATURE CONSERVANCY WILL PARTNER WITH THE WORLD FISH MIGRATION FOUNDATION TO RAISE AWARENESS AND CAPACITY FOR RIVER RESTORATION FOR MIGRATORY FISH AND RELATED TRUST SPECIES. NOAA FUNDS WILL SUPPORT COMMUNICATIONS STAFF AND CAPACITY, AS WELL AS THE GLOBAL NETWORK OF THE WORLD FISH MIGRATION FOUNDATION TO WORK WITH NOAA COMMUNICATIONS STAFF TO ENGAGE NATIONAL AND INTERNATIONAL AUDIENCES. THIS WILL INCLUDE LIVE INTERVIEWS FROM RESTORATION SITES AND WITH ECONOMIC EXPERTS FROM NOAA, AND WILL ALSO HIGHLIGHT NOAA RESTORATION WORK AND CONNECT TO NORTH AMERICAN AND GLOBAL EFFORTS THROUGH A WEBINAR FORMAT. THIS ONGOING RECOGNITION AND CELEBRATION SURROUNDING WORLD FISH MIGRATION DAY WILL BE A SIGNIFICANT OPPORTUNITY TO NETWORK AND DEVELOP PARTNERSHIPS.

THE POKAGON BAND OF POTAWATOMI WILL RESTORE A SECTION OF THE DOWAGIAC RIVER CONTAINED WITHIN TRIBAL PROPERTIES UPSTREAM OF THE OLD PUCKER STREET DAM LOCATION SITE, WHICH WAS REMOVED IN 2021. BUILDING ON A COMPLEMENTARY HABITAT RESTORATION PROJECT IN THE RIVER, THIS PROJECT WILL RESTORE HISTORIC MEANDERS, RESTORE HYDROLOGY TO WETLANDS ON TRIBAL PROPERTY, AND PROVIDE IMPROVED HABITAT FOR MULTIPLE FISH SPECIES, INCLUDING SMALLMOUTH BASS, WALLEYE AND NORTHERN PIKE. THE PROJECT SUPPORTS THE EFFORTS OF FOCUS AREA 4 WITHIN THE GREAT LAKES RESTORATION INITIATIVE ACTION PLAN III AND THE ENVIRONMENTAL PRIORITIES OF THE LAKE MICHIGAN COMMITTEE.

THE GREAT LAKES FISHERY COMMISSION HAS PARTNERED WITH NOAA TO CARRY OUT HABITAT RESTORATION PROJECTS PRIORITIZED BY THE LAKE COMMITTEES TO RESTORE HABITAT FOR NATIVE GREAT LAKES FISH SPECIES THROUGHOUT GREAT LAKES RIVERINE HABITATS AND COASTAL WETLANDS. THE PARTNERSHIP FOCUSES ON RESTORATION AND CONNECTIVITY OF COASTAL WETLANDS AND RIVER CORRIDORS TO RESTORE FISH PASSAGE AND WETLAND HABITATS IN SUPPORT OF NATIVE POPULATIONS OF FISH AND WILDLIFE. THE FOLLOWING PROJECTS WILL RECEIVE TECHNICAL AND FINANCIAL SUPPORT IN THE FIRST YEAR OF THE AWARD:  NEBAGAMON CREEK CULVERT REMOVAL PROJECT - DOUGLAS COUNTY, WISCONSIN   INNER SAGINAW BAY REEF RESTORATION PROJECT - BAY COUNTY, MI   SALMON RIVER TRESTLE POOL PROJECT - OSWEGO COUNTY, NY  FLAT ROCK/HUROC DAM FISH PASSAGE PROJECT - WAYNE COUNTY, MI

THE MUSKEGON COUNTY DRAIN COMMISSIONER WILL CONDUCT A FEASIBILITY STUDY AND DEVELOP CONSTRUCTION DESIGNS TO RECONNECT TWO SHALLOW WATER LAKES, LOCALLY KNOWN AS THE MONA LAKE CELERY FLATS, TO BLACK CREEK AND SUBSEQUENTLY MONA LAKE, A DROWNED RIVER MOUTH THAT CONNECTS DIRECTLY TO LAKE MICHIGAN. THE MONA LAKE WATERSHED IS LOCATED IN CENTRAL-WESTERN MICHIGAN AND HAS BEEN SEVERELY IMPACTED BY HISTORIC LAND USE PRACTICES. THE PROPOSED PROJECT WILL INCREASE RESILIENCY OF AQUATIC SPECIES, SUCH AS THE GREAT LAKES SPOTTED MUSKELLUNGE AND OTHER SPECIES OF CONCERN, THAT ARE SIGNIFICANT TO THE GREAT LAKES ECOSYSTEM. THIS PROJECT ALSO ADVANCES THE GOALS OF FOCUS AREA 4 OF THE GREAT LAKES RESTORATION INITIATIVE ACTION PLAN III AND THE ENVIRONMENTAL PRIORITIES OF THE LAKE MICHIGAN COMMITTEE.

THIS AWARD WILL ALLOW THE NATIONAL FISH AND WILDLIFE FOUNDATION TO PARTNER WITH THE NOAA DAMAGE ASSESSMENT, REMEDIATION, AND RESTORATION PROGRAM (DARRP) TO IMPLEMENT PRIORITY RESTORATION ACTIVITIES RELATED TO NATURAL RESOURCE DAMAGES.  BASED ON ASSESSMENTS AND ANALYSIS BY TRUSTEE COUNCILS, THE RESTORATION ACTIVITIES ARE INTENDED TO COMPENSATE FOR NATURAL RESOURCE INJURIES FOLLOWING OIL SPILLS AND RELEASES OF HAZARDOUS SUBSTANCES, AND LOST USE OF NATURAL RESOURCES DUE TO THOSE INJURIES.

THIS AWARD WILL ALLOW THE NATURE CONSERVANCY TO PARTNER WITH CONSERVATION CORPS ORGANIZATIONS ACROSS THE GULF OF MEXICO TO CREATE CONSERVATION JOBS FOR YOUTH.  THIS PROJECT WILL USE FUNDS PROVIDED BY THE RESTORE ACT TO CONTINUE THE GULFCORPS PROGRAM, WHICH WILL PROVIDE SUSTAINABLE AND LASTING BENEFITS TO THE ENVIRONMENT, ECONOMY, AND COMMUNITIES ALONG THE GULF OF MEXICO THAT HAVE BEEN IMPACTED BY THE DEEPWATER HORIZON OIL SPILL.  THE GULFCORPS PROGRAM WILL PROVIDE LABOR FOR ON-THE-GROUND RESTORATION BENEFITING COASTAL HABITATS AND WATER QUALITY. THESE PROJECTS WILL ALSO PROVIDE SHORT-TERM EMPLOYMENT FOR LOCAL CITIZENS, SKILLS TRAINING, AND EXPERIENCE IN RESTORATION-BASED JOBS WHICH COULD SUPPORT LOCAL WORKFORCE DEVELOPMENT IN THIS FIELD.  CREWS WILL LIKELY PARTICIPATE IN PROJECTS SUCH AS INVASIVE SPECIES REMOVAL, SHORELINE STABILIZATION, MARSH AND RIPARIAN RE-VEGETATION, SHELLFISH RESTORATION, AND IMPROVING RECREATIONAL AMENITIES.  PROJECTS WILL BE PRIORITIZED AND SELECTED BY NOAA, OUR

THE "RESTORING CRITICAL CONNECTIVITY IN THE PISCATAQUIS RIVER: ADVANCING ATLANTIC SALMON RECOVERY IN THE PENOBSCOT SHRU" PROJECT WILL WORK TOWARD RESTORING ACCESS TO MORE THAN 10,000 UNITS OF DESIGNATED CRITICAL HABITAT FOR ENDANGERED ATLANTIC SALMON, A NOAA SPECIES IN THE SPOTLIGHT. THE SITES ARE LOCATED IN THE PISCATAQUIS RIVER WATERSHED WITHIN THE PENOBSCOT SALMON HABITAT RECOVERY UNIT (SHRU), IN THE STATE OF MAINE. THESE PROJECTS WILL BENEFIT ATLANTIC SALMON, AS WELL AS CO-EVOLVED DIADROMOUS FISH AND OTHER AQUATIC ORGANISMS, THROUGH DAM REMOVAL AND REPLACEMENT OF IMPASSABLE CULVERTS IN CRITICAL HEADWATER HABITAT. THE NATURE CONSERVANCY WILL COMPLETE THE FINAL ENGINEERING DESIGN FOR THE REMOVAL OF THE GUILFORD DAM AND RESTORATION OF THE ADJACENT FLOODPLAIN, WHICH WILL ULTIMATELY RECONNECT MORE THAN 9,738 SUITABLE HABITAT UNITS FOR ATLANTIC SALMON IN THE PISCATAQUIS WATERSHED ABOVE THE DAM. IN ADDITION, THE PROJECT WILL RESTORE ACCESS TO HIGH-QUALITY, RESILIENT HABI

THE "CONNECTIVITY AND HABITAT SUITABILITY RESTORATION IN THE DOWNEAST MAINE ATLANTIC SALMON SHRU" PROJECT WILL RESTORE ACCESS TO DESIGNATED CRITICAL HABITAT FOR ENDANGERED ATLANTIC SALMON, A NOAA SPECIES IN THE SPOTLIGHT, THROUGH THE REPLACEMENT OF UNDERSIZED CULVERTS. THE SITES ARE LOCATED IN THE WATERSHEDS OF THE DENNYS, MACHIAS, PLEASANT, UNION, AND NARRAGUAGUS RIVERS IN THE DOWNEAST COASTAL SALMON HABITAT RECOVERY UNIT (SHRU), IN THE STATE OF MAINE. PROJECT SHARE WILL COMPLETE 13 ROAD/STREAM CROSSING PROJECTS, WHICH WILL CONNECT NEARLY 700 HABITAT UNITS ACROSS THE WATERSHEDS. HABITAT SUITABILITY IMPROVEMENTS USING TECHNIQUES SUCH AS ENGINEERED LOG JAMS WILL BE CONDUCTED IN 550 HABITAT UNITS WITHIN MAINSTEM AND TRIBUTARY REACHES. IN ADDITION, FEASIBILITY STUDIES WILL BE CONDUCTED TO IMPROVE FISH PASSAGE FOR ATLANTIC SALMON AND OTHER SEA-RUN FISH LIKE ALEWIFE AND AMERICAN EEL TO 375 SALMON HABITAT UNITS AT THE GREAT WORKS DAM AND MARION FALLS FISHWAY ON CATHANCE STR

THE "RECONNECTING CRITICAL HABITAT OF THE SANDY RIVER PROJECT" WILL RESTORE ACCESS TO MORE THAN 2,697 UNITS OF DESIGNATED CRITICAL HABITAT FOR ENDANGERED ATLANTIC SALMON, A NOAA SPECIES IN THE SPOTLIGHT. THE PROJECTS ARE LOCATED IN THE KENNEBEC RIVER WATERSHED WITHIN THE MERRYMEETING BAY SALMON HABITAT RECOVERY UNIT (SHRU), IN THE STATE OF MAINE. THE ATLANTIC SALMON FEDERATION WILL REMOVE THE WALTON'S MILL DAM ON THE LOWER MAINSTEM OF TEMPLE STREAM AND REPLACE THE ASSOCIATED PUBLIC WATER LINE CURRENTLY CROSSING THE IMPOUNDMENT, AND WILL REPLACE FOUR UNDERSIZED ROAD/STREAM CROSSINGS ON COLD-WATER TRIBUTARIES TO THE SANDY RIVER. THESE FIVE PROJECTS WILL RESTORE ACCESS TO 2,301 SALMON CRITICAL HABITAT UNITS, AND WILL ALSO IMPROVE HABITAT CONNECTIVITY FOR AMERICAN EEL, ALEWIVES, BLUEBACK HERRING, EASTERN BROOK TROUT, AND VARIOUS OTHER AQUATIC ORGANISMS. CALTROUT WILL BE AWARDED $490,167 TO RESTORE OFF-CHANNEL HABITAT ON THE MAD RIVER, WHICH DRAINS 497 SQUARE MILES OVER A LENGTH OF ROUGHLY 100 MILES TO THE PACIFIC OCEAN, 6 MILES NORTH OF HUMBOLDT BAY. THE RIVER OFFERS CLOSE TO 50 MILES OF SPAWNING AND REARING HABITAT BUT IS SEVERELY LIMITED IN ESTUARINE AND OFF-CHANNEL HABITAT TO SUPPORT REARING WINTER JUVENILE SALMONIDS. THE PROJECT IS LOCATED WITHIN TIDAL INFLUENCE, AT APPROXIMATELY 3 MILES FROM THE MOUTH OF THE MAD RIVER. THE PROJECT AREA CURRENTLY CONTAINS LEVEED PERCOLATION PONDS IN THE FLOODPLAIN THAT WERE USED AS PART OF A DEFUNCT WASTEWATER MANAGEMENT FACILITY. THE PERCOLATION PONDS WERE CONSTRUCTED ON THE ACTIVE FLOODPLAIN IN 1983 AND ARE NOW BEING DECOMMISSIONED, OFFERING THE OPPORTUNITY TO REPURPOSE THE LAND FOR IMPROVED ECOSYSTEM FUNCTION - BUILDING OFF-CHANNEL PONDS THAT PROVIDE WINTER JUVENILE SALMONID HABITAT, AND EXPANDED RIPARIAN FOREST.
